hostNotes: Welcome to our family trivia night! Each round has different formats. Read questions clearly and give teams time to discuss. Have fun with it!

rounds.name: The Warm-Up Round
rounds.description: A mix of general knowledge to get everyone's brains firing. 2 points per correct answer.

questions.question: On average, which planet is actually closest to Earth - not Venus, but this small, fast-orbiting world?
questions.funFact: While Venus comes closer to Earth at times, Mercury's tighter orbit around the Sun means it's actually nearest to Earth on average - about 1.04 AU compared to Venus at 1.14 AU.

questions.question: Author Joe Hill successfully published novels for 10 years before revealing his famous father's identity. Who is his father?
questions.funFact: Joe Hill is the author of 'Horns' and 'NOS4A2'. He deliberately kept his parentage secret to succeed on his own merits.

questions.question: Doritos corn chips were actually invented at a restaurant in which famous theme park?
questions.funFact: Arch West created Doritos at Casa de Fritos in Disneyland in 1966, using leftover tortillas that were being thrown away.

questions.question: What is a single strand of spaghetti called?
questions.funFact: In Italian, 'spaghetti' is actually the plural form. The singular 'spaghetto' comes from 'spago' meaning 'string' or 'twine'.

questions.question: In Sedona, Arizona, McDonald's uses what unusual color instead of their traditional golden arches yellow?
questions.funFact: Sedona officials worried the yellow would clash with the red rock scenery, making it the only McDonald's in the world with turquoise arches.

questions.question: Gary Larson's 'The Far Side' comic invented a joke name for the spikes on a Stegosaurus tail. What term, now used by actual scientists, did he create?
questions.hostHint: The joke was that it was named 'after the late Thag Simmons'
questions.funFact: Paleontologists loved it so much they adopted 'thagomizer' as the actual scientific term - it now appears in academic papers!

questions.question: What fruit can be found at the very top of the men's Wimbledon trophy?
questions.funFact: The pineapple was a symbol of hospitality in 18th century England, when the trophy was designed. Pineapples were so rare they were often rented for display at parties!

questions.question: Google Images was invented because of the massive search demand for photos of what celebrity wearing a specific green dress at the 2000 Grammys?
questions.funFact: The Versace jungle dress caused so many image searches that Google realized they needed a dedicated image search. The dress has its own Wikipedia page!

questions.question: Before 'cheese' became the standard, what word did photographers in the 1800s tell subjects to say before taking their picture?
questions.funFact: Victorians thought smiling in photos was undignified, so 'prunes' was chosen specifically because it made a serious, puckered expression!

questions.question: What is a group of flamingos called?
questions.funFact: Flamingos aren't born pink - they hatch with gray/white feathers and only turn pink from eating brine shrimp and blue-green algae.

rounds.name: Through the Decades
rounds.description: Pop culture spanning the generations! Something for everyone. 3 points per correct answer.

questions.question: In 1973, Billie Jean King defeated Bobby Riggs in a famous tennis match watched by 90 million viewers. What was this event called?
questions.funFact: King won in straight sets 6-4, 6-3, 6-3. Riggs had previously beaten Margaret Court, the world #1, which set up this showdown.

questions.question: Gary Dahl became a millionaire in 1975 by selling what inanimate objects as 'pets' - complete with a carrying case and care instructions?
questions.funFact: The Pet Rock fad lasted about 6 months but sold over 1.5 million rocks at $4 each. Dahl made about $15 million before the fad died.

questions.question: Originally given the Japanese title 'Puckman' before being renamed for Western audiences, what 1980s arcade game was later named 'Most Successful Coin-Operated Game' by Guinness?
questions.funFact: It was renamed from 'Puckman' because arcade operators worried vandals would change the P to an F. Smart move!

questions.question: 'Babyland General Hospital' was the fictional birthplace of which wildly popular 1980s collectible dolls, each with their own birth certificate?
questions.funFact: The 1983 Christmas shopping frenzy for these dolls caused actual riots, with some stores using riot gear to control crowds.

questions.question: Which Britpop band had their biggest US hit in 1997 with the explosive 'Song 2,' making everyone yell 'Woo-hoo!'?
questions.funFact: The song was written as a parody of American grunge rock, but ironically became their only US hit and is now a stadium anthem.

questions.question: In 1997, what Spanish pop duo released the song that sparked a worldwide dance craze with a distinctive arm-crossing move?
questions.funFact: The Macarena spent 14 weeks at #1 on the Billboard Hot 100. Both members of Los del Río were in their 60s when it became a hit!

questions.question: In 2002, what animated movie took home the first-ever Academy Award for Best Animated Feature?
questions.funFact: Shrek beat out Monsters Inc. and Jimmy Neutron. The category was created because animation had become so sophisticated it deserved its own award.

questions.question: The internet prank where Rick Astley's 'Never Gonna Give You Up' music video is unexpectedly planted into an unrelated link became popular around 2008. What is this called?
questions.funFact: By 2021, the original video had over 1 billion views. Rick Astley himself has said he finds it hilarious and feels honored.

questions.question: What fantasy TV series holds the record for the most Emmy Awards won by a drama series, with 59 total wins?
questions.funFact: The show won Best Drama 4 times and ran for 8 seasons. The finale was watched by 19.3 million viewers.

questions.question: SING-OFF BONUS: The host will play or hum the opening notes. Teams must identify 'Bohemian Rhapsody' by Queen. For full points, what year was this epic 6-minute song released?
questions.hostHint: Hum 'Is this the real life? Is this just fantasy?' - Award 2 points for the song title, 1 bonus point for the correct year.
questions.funFact: The song was considered too long for radio at 5:55, but became the third best-selling UK single of all time.

rounds.name: Lightning Round
rounds.description: Speed counts! Quick answers, 1 point each. First team to shout it out wins the point!
rounds.hostNotes: Read these FAST! Teams shout out answers. First correct answer wins. Keep the energy up!

questions.question: In what year did the Times Square ball drop tradition begin?
How many grapes do Spaniards traditionally eat at midnight on New Year's Eve - one for each chime of the clock?
South Africa has three capital cities. Name ANY one of them.
What 1965 space mission made 'Jingle Bells' the first song ever played in space?
What cute name did astronomers give to the Universe's average color - a beige shade close to white?
Robert Burns wrote 'Auld Lang Syne' in 1788. What do the words 'auld lang syne' mean in English?
In what color underwear do Italians traditionally dress on New Year's Eve for good luck?
Marie Curie won Nobel Prizes in two different scientific fields. Name either one.
What 2010 Christopher Nolan film features dreams within dreams and a spinning top?
What show about a chemistry teacher turned drug lord won the Emmy for Outstanding Drama Series twice?
How many times do Japanese temples ring their bells to welcome the new year?
The Times Square ball weighs about how many pounds - 1,000, 6,000, or 12,000?
When Twitter launched in 2006, posts were limited to how many characters?
In the American South, what are you supposed to eat on New Year's Day for prosperity - the greens represent money?
acceptableAnswers: Black eyed peas and collard greens

questions.question: Final question! Due to the International Date Line, what Pacific island nation celebrates New Year's first each year?

bonusQuestions.description: Use if you need a tiebreaker or want extra fun!
bonusQuestions.question: SING-OFF: Each team has 30 seconds to sing as many song titles as they can that include a NUMBER in the title (e.g., 'I Got 99 Problems', 'One More Night'). One point per unique song!
bonusQuestions.hostHint: Keep a tally. If a song is repeated by another team, neither gets the point for that one!

bonusQuestions.question: CLOSEST GUESS: The Times Square New Year's Eve ball contains how many LED lights? (Hint: it's over 30,000)
bonusQuestions.hostHint: Closest guess without going over wins, Price is Right style!

bonusQuestions.question: CLOSEST GUESS: What percentage of New Year's resolutions are typically abandoned by February?
bonusQuestions.hostHint: Accept anything from 75-85% as correct. It's higher than most people think!

scoringRules.bonusPoints: Available for creative rounds - host discretion
